channel.title: Comments on: In a high building there is so much to do…

item.title: By: Eric Greenwood
item.dc:creator: Eric Greenwood
item.description: that makes sense. and i agree that the sentiment of a favorite album can eventually take on a life of its own, since people naturally romanticize positive aspects of the past.
item.content:encoded: that makes sense. and i agree that the sentiment of a favorite album can eventually take on a life of its own, since people naturally romanticize positive aspects of the past.

item.title: By: Tom
item.dc:creator: Tom
item.description: Thanks for the response - I should probably have expanded the Peel bit slightly, the discussion the article was born out of focused on "Teenage Kicks" as Peel's favourite song, and I never intended to suggest that an allegiance to allegiance itself was shallow, quite the reverse! What I was trying to get at is that TK and TMR for Peel had taken on more of the sentiment he had towards Liverpool FC, say: an unbreakable bone-deep fandom (whatever its initial cause).
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the response – I should probably have expanded the Peel bit slightly, the discussion the article was born out of focused on “Teenage Kicks” as Peel’s favourite song, and I never intended to suggest that an allegiance to allegiance itself was shallow, quite the reverse! What I was trying to get at is that TK and TMR for Peel had taken on more of the sentiment he had towards Liverpool FC, say: an unbreakable bone-deep fandom (whatever its initial cause).
